You are really brightening our days and bringing positive energy to the ACS staff! Yet another reason to love Alton Central School and the Alton community!

Thank you so much for your kindness and continuous support!

post_text:
It is our distinct pleasure to congratulate Alton Central School's very own 7th grade extraordinaire, Jena Bald, for winning 3rd place in the New Hampshire Association for Middle Level Education 2019- 2020 "We Love Our School Because" Video Contest!!!!!!!

Jena wrote, produced and edited an excellent video that showcased what she loves about ACS!

Jena has worked tirelessly all year as a producer for ACS news, the MC for our assemblies, and the producer and host of our "What is it?" segment. This win is well deserved, as she has quickly become a great talent in the field media arts.

Thank you Jena, and all of ACS for making our school so great! We are all so proud of you!

Also, a special thank you goes out to Mr. Dumond for his assistance and guidance on this amazing project!

You can see the video here - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tiJKmjURTX4

post_text:
Good Morning Alton Central School Families,
Before we leave for the long weekend, I wanted to share a slideshow that we have put together as a dedication to all of our ACS students. We love and miss you all and truly can’t wait for the day we can be together again at ACS!

Special thanks to Ms. Riendeau for the idea, Mr. Neveu for the music, our ACS staff, and to Mr. Pfenninger for putting it together and making this dream become a reality in our current world of uncertainty!

Have a great weekend everybody!

-Mr. Mac

Hello Alton Central School Families!

We are very excited to announce a virtual visit by poet Meg Kearney on Wednesday and Thursday of this week. All students will have the opportunity to hear Meg read her book Trouper, view a presentation by Meg, and meet her live to ask questions. Please see the Scrolling Banner for a complete schedule of her in-person virtual visit and other resources. We look forward to seeing you all in cyberspace with Meg!

Please see the Scrolling Banner for a complete schedule of her in-person virtual visit and other resources. We look forward to seeing you all in cyberspace with Meg!

post_text:
Good afternoon ACS Families,
Please see the press release regarding the Atlantic Broadband launch of a No/Low-Cost Internet Option.

Atlantic Broadband Internet Assist: Atlantic Broadband has introduced “Atlantic Broadband Internet Assist” for a limited time for residents in need in its service areas who do not presently have internet with Atlantic Broadband. The new 15 x 1 Mbps service, normally priced at $9.99 per month plus taxes, will be offered free for 60 days. New Atlantic Broadband Internet Assist customers also will receive free installation and a free modem with the service.

Hope this finds folks that need it.

Be Well Everyone, we miss you all!

New Atlantic Broadband Internet Assist customers also will receive free installation and a free modem with the service.

Hope this finds folks that need it.

Be Well Everyone, we miss you all!

post_text:
Hello ACS Families,

As we officially start our remote learning, I would like to remind everyone that help resources are available by clicking on the scrolling banner found at the top of MyAcs.org. These resources include parent information on how to talk about Covid-19, contact information for Guidance resources, and instructions for students on how to access online resources.

Students should be going to Google Classroom to find their classwork. A short how-to is found here: https://youtu.be/z7VzjTrI5vM

If students need to contact their teachers, they can do so through Gmail and Google Hangouts. How-To: https://youtu.be/bD8sxoBrC2c

Teachers will have the ability to video conference with students who need 1 on 1 support and will have set office hours found within their Google Classroom sites when students can contact them with any questions.

If you would like to order brown bag meals from ACS, the form is now live and accepting responses. It can be found at: https://forms.gle/q9XvQdnK6ZfduNn87

The office is available should you have any questions or concerns: (603) 875-7500.

post_text:
NJHS Pi(e) Day is tomorrow. Slices will be sold for $1.50 during lunches. Proceeds will benefit Make-a-Wish Foundation.

Please note that all pies will be purchased from Market Basket in order to ensure that safe kitchen procedures have been followed. Students will wear gloves and follow safe serving procedures while slicing and serving.

If you have already baked a pie, NJHS thanks you for your support, and hopes that you enjoy eating it in the comfort of your home. Please do not send homemade pies to school.

Thank you!

Shay

Shaleen Cassily, Ph.D., M.S.Ed.

Director of Curriculum and Instruction

Alton Central School

41 School Street

Alton, NH 03809

(603) 875-7500

post_text:
A Great Incentive from the Boys and Girls Club... Don't miss out!!!

We are offering a free week to the first 12 members to enroll!

We are offering 5 days a week for $50. Daily contract rates are also available.

The Boys & Girls Club of Alton is now up and running! We are so excited to offer this opportunity to our community. The program is staffed by our own ACS educators- Marianne Clegg, Sarah Guillemette, & Pam Forbes, with substitute staff, Eric Dickson & Sandy Flanagan. We are offering a wide variety of activities, including cooking, art, board games, STEM challenges, and cooperative learning opportunities. We are also able to work with classroom teachers to provide support on homework, along with any other academic needs.

Come join us at the club!

Contact Julie Rothemund, Lakes Region School Age Manager at jrothemund@centralnhclubs.org for information & enrollment.

post_text:
Just a reminder...
Make sure to check out the Gilman Library this summer! Any student who stops by the library will get to check out wicked cool books for free AND will earn a free ice cream at River Run. Students who keep track of their hours reading can also enter a raffle for prizes at the library, earning 1 ticket for every hour reading in the month of July. (There is plenty of time left)

You could read on a boat
You could read on a goat
You could read in on a train
You could read in the rain
You could read with a mouse
You could read at your house
You can read here or there
You can read anywhere!

As you spend your days reading over the summer, be sure to take a selfie wherever you are reading and post it to the ACS Padlet wall! The padlet wall can be found using the link below:

https://padlet.com/jleathers1/summer

We hope you are all having a wonderful summer!

Just a reminder...
Make sure to check out the Gilman Library this summer! Any student who stops by the library will get to check out wicked cool books for free AND will earn a free ice cream at River Run. Students who keep track of their hours reading can also enter a raffle for prizes at the library, earning 1 ticket for every hour reading in the month of July. (There is plenty of time left)

You could read on a boat
You could read on a goat
You could read in on a train
You could read in the rain
You could read with a mouse
You could read at your house
You can read here or there
You can read anywhere!

As you spend your days reading over the summer, be sure to take a selfie wherever you are reading and post it to the ACS Padlet wall! The padlet wall can be found using the link below:

https://padlet.com/jleathers1/summer

We hope you are all having a wonderful summer!

PADLET.COM
Summer Reading Is Cool!

post_text:
Detective Adam Painchaud and Officer Kristen Guest presented a gun safety lesson to Alton Central School’s Kindergarten through Third Grades. Eddie Eagle Gunsafe program is a fun prevention education tool that helps parents, police officers, communities, and educators navigate a topic that is paramount to our safety. We had so much fun.

Eddie, his Wing Team, and the Alton Police Department are on a mission to help teach kids what to do if they ever come across a gun - whether or not they think it’s “real.”

🛑 Stop Don’t Touch 🏃 Runaway Tell a Grown Up!

Ask your kids to talk to you about what they know about gun safety! Check out the following link for more resources: https://eddieeagle.nra.org/

post_text:
Forum Facebook Report March 2019

Grade 3 students discussed getting a picnic table for coloring outside and having occasional ice cream days.
Grade 4 students talked about the importance of a person's place in line when going out and coming in from recess.
Grade 5 students wanted to know why they could not play video games here at school.
Grade 6 students would like more bleachers for outside with padding.
Grade 7 and 8 students discussed social issues, and shared goal setting and self advocacy tips to become more independent.

post_text:
Dear Parents/Guardians,
The events of the day remind us that even here in our small town, unspeakable tragedies can occur. Although the family involved is not enrolled at Alton Central, community ties between neighbors can bring about strong emotions. If your child feels the need to talk with a guidance counselor, or any other adult they feel comfortable with, please contact Mr. MacArthur at 875-7500 or jmacarthur@sau72.org so that he can ensure that the contact is made.
A thank you to the staff and administration at ACS for their calm and professional handling of the situation. Your children are in good hands.

Warmest Regards,

Pam Stiles

Superintendent, SAU 72

post_text:
Hello Alton Central School Families,
This is John MacArthur, principal of Alton Central School.

I just wanted follow up from my previous message to let you know that we have lifted the “Secure Campus” and are now “All Clear.” All students and staff are and continue to be safe here at Alton Central School.

Our school day will resume as normal including pickup and drop off for our PreK program.

I want to thank the Alton Police Department, and the ACS Staff and students for their support and cooperation this morning.

Thank you and have a great remainder of your day.
text:
Hello Alton Central School Families,
This is John MacArthur, principal of Alton Central School.

I just wanted follow up from my previous message to let you know that we have lifted the “Secure Campus” and are now “All Clear.” All students and staff are and continue to be safe here at Alton Central School.

Our school day will resume as normal including pickup and drop off for our PreK program.

I want to thank the Alton Police Department, and the ACS Staff and students for their support and cooperation this morning.

Thank you and have a great remainder of your day.

post_text:
Good Morning Alton Families,
This is John MacArthur, Principal of Alton Central School.

We have received information from the Alton Police Department regarding a shooting that occurred in the town of Alton near the New Durham town line.

There is no current threat to ACS. As a precautionary measure we have activated a secure campus. Nobody is permitted in or out of the building until we are given an all clear.

Again, ACS is secure and safe.

We will keep you updated.

Good Morning Alton Families,

There is no current threat to ACS. As a precautionary measure we have activated a secure campus. Nobody is permitted in or out of the building until we are given an all clear.

Again, ACS is secure and safe.

We will keep you updated.

post_text:
FEBRUARY STUDENT FORUM UPDATE:

During the February 3rd grade forum students discussed homework; their likes, dislikes and even the purpose of it. The 4th and 5th grade forums focused on the noise level during lunch and unkind behavior towards one another. The 6th grade forum saw discussion of "See Something, Say Something" communication opportunities, field trips and homework. Both the 7th and 8th grade forums addressed goal setting, improving grades, and taking advantage of different opportunities here at school.

post_text:
Weather Update for Wednesday 2/13/19

We currently have an early release day scheduled for Wednesday, February 13th.

However, winter weather has been predicted and we have had enough interruptions!

Here are three possible scenarios for the “iffy” weather situation for Wednesday:

1. IF the meteorologists are completely wrong and this whole mess goes out to sea….we will have an early release as planned.
2. IF we get hit with snow but roads are cleared in time for a delayed opening, we will welcome students at 9:30 and finish the day at our regular time of 2:50. This means we would not have an early release day, just a delayed opening.
3. IF the roads are NOT cleared, then school will be closed.

Regardless - We will update you on Wednesday morning with the official closing status but wanted to give you a heads up to plan accordingly.

Unfortunately we cannot change the weather, but also want to be sure that we are not in school all the way until July…. Yes, we still love New England...

J. MacArthur ACS Principal
text:
Weather Update for Wednesday 2/13/19

We currently have an early release day scheduled for Wednesday, February 13th.

However, winter weather has been predicted and we have had enough interruptions!

Here are three possible scenarios for the “iffy” weather situation for Wednesday:

1. IF the meteorologists are completely wrong and this whole mess goes out to sea….we will have an early release as planned.
2. IF we get hit with snow but roads are cleared in time for a delayed opening, we will welcome students at 9:30 and finish the day at our regular time of 2:50. This means we would not have an early release day, just a delayed opening.
3. IF the roads are NOT cleared, then school will be closed.

Regardless - We will update you on Wednesday morning with the official closing status but wanted to give you a heads up to plan accordingly.

Unfortunately we cannot change the weather, but also want to be sure that we are not in school all the way until July…. Yes, we still love New England...

J. MacArthur ACS Principal

post_text: The Annual Deliberative Budget Session will be held on Saturday, February 2 at PMHS at 1PM. Childcare will be provided, beginning at 12:45, by the PMHS National Honor Society. Budget materials can be found at myacs.org under the SAU 72 tab, "School Election, Warrant Articles, & Deliberative Sessions". All handouts will be available at the Deliberative Session.

post_text:
Hello Alton Central School Ski Families,

Tomorrow is projected to be colder and windy with highs just reaching the double digits. Please be sure to remind your child to dress in layers and address any exposed skin areas. Scarves, neck warmers or partial face masks are a great asset on days like these. Our chaperones will bring students into the lodges more frequently. As always, we have staff designated to stay in the lodge with students who need a break.

As a reminder, we are only able to reschedule one week of our programming, this is generally reserved for weeks in which school is canceled or delayed.

post_text: In an effort to help ACS students to have a more positive and productive learning experience at school, grade-level forums were created/designed to hear their concerns. As a result of questions recently posed to students, it was revealed that they have concerns about their grades, work load, social issues, and the motivation to do well in school. Conversations held during the forums focused on contributing factors and possible solutions. These forums will continue to meet monthly in order to encourage open and honest communication, empowering students to positively affect their own learning experiences.

post_text: TIGER sighting at ACS!!! TIGER is a performing group out of PSU that tours throughout New England. The group centers their entire performance around the writings of children and is based on difficult social issues. The students really loved the message and performances today!

post_text:
2018 School Tax Rate Explanation

The School Board is aware of questions that have arisen regarding the 2018 school tax rate. Although 33 cents less than 3 years ago and 5 cents less than two years ago, the comparative rate to 2017 was difficult to understand.

In 2017 the school tax rate decreased substantially compared to prior years because the below events had impact in same year:
1. Lower budget/warrants
2. Offset due to significant return of funds to Town from prior year budget savings
3. $135 million increase in valuation compared to previous years

Therefore, while the 2018 rate is reduced compared with 2015 and 2016, the dip in the tax rate and savings to taxpayers in 2017 was an anomaly.

Further explanation with a related tax history of 2015-2018 can be found by clicking here: https://www.myacs.org/Page/1980 or at www.myacs.org,at the SAU tab under “School Election, Warrant Articles, & Deliberative Sessions”, 2019. Information about the proposed 2019-20 budget and warrant articles can be found at the same location.
